After hours of work, hours of journeys. After slaying idols and achieving all there is to achieve, I stood atop a throne of relics, white through red, and I pondered the name of the game that I play. Risk Of Rain 2, why is it named this way? And then I looped yet again, tens of stages behind me, and I cut through the foes like a blade through butter. Everywhere I went, a flurry of destruction followed. Missiles, flames, electricity and knives poured down from the sky as if the gods were bleeding. Death was all that could be heard as the world came to a jeering halt. And there I stared at my frozen world, and from a distance I learned the reason for this game's name. Bullets, hellfire, the very cargo that I wield is the rain. The risk? That's me.
And with the frozen scene I realize one other thing... I need a better PC.

Everytime I think Gearbox fixed the game I find another disappointing change that did not need to happen. Captain hack beacons no longer make shrines of chance free. I waited weeks after the seekers of the storm dlc for gearbox to just return the state of the base game as it once was on pc only to be find more changes like this. I loved this game but I can't bear to play it and find more unwelcome changes. 

If you enjoy the game in the state that it is I am happy for you. I can't find that for myself so I'm going to let this game rot in my library.

It's a polished roguelike with a good amount of depth to it, but it isn't for everyone. 

-Map designs are large, but enemies can be small or float in mid-air way above, which I find annoying. 
-Platforming is important as you'll want to reach rare items higher up, so it becomes an annoying loop of finding where you need to jump to, and it's an accidental mispress or being shot at, means falling off the platform so you have to start all over again. 
-This map rewards exploration, and the crates where you find loot/healing are tiny and spread across a large map. 
-In order to progress to the next level, you have to find the teleporter first, which can be annoying as you'll have to explore the large map just to find it. If you miss it, expect to waste more time running across the map again. 
-The game has a mechanic where it gets progressively more difficult as you play, so the large maps and platforming are there to waste your time so the game can get harder. 

I'd return it if I could.

I guess I should actually review this, so here:

The whole point of this game is to build up a character making them more powerful by collecting items. I was having a TON of fun doing so. Personally, I hate using guides because that ruins all the fun of finding what works. I guess I should have read at least one about how much bullshit mithrix is. Anyways, today I had my best run ever. I was melting / exploding enemies 0.2 seconds after they spawned. Nothing stood a chance. Not even the first 3 phases of the final boss. It felt amazing finally having a run with a build that worked. But then, the 4th stage of the final boss TAKES ALL MY ITEMS AWAY AND IMMEDIATELY FUCKING ONE SHOTS ME, ENDING ALL THE FUCKING WORK I PUT IN COLLECTING ITEMS!!! What was the fucking point of it all? Why would I want to play again? Making a different build will make no difference in fighting mithrix. All those items mean nothing. The devs should just remove everything from the game and make a single stage where you fight the final boss with no items because that's the "real" point / challenge / purpose of this game anyways. Mithrix should have been a special stage or challenge boss. Making it the final boss of the main game is so counter intuitive to the entire game design of character building I actually can't believe anyone would think it's a good idea and I'm convinced they just wanted to piss people off. I mean, why would you ruin such a fun game by nulling the main hook of the gameplay?

In fact...

This shit pissed me off SO MUCH I literally wrote my FIRST review ever.

DO NOT PLAY RoR2 UNLESS YOU ENJOY BEING PISSED OFF BY THE, ABSOLUTE, MOST UNFAIR BULLSHIT I'VE SEEN IN ANY GAME EVER!!!

If the devs would remove 4th phase mithrix from the main game and make it an optional extra fight then this game would go straight to recommened.

Is this a good game? Yeah. It is. The dedicated fans can tell you here or on YouTube. However, the rest of this is me expressing frustration as I uninstall the game a third time.

The apologists say, "when you die it always feels like your fault." I've heard that a few times. It just isn't simply the case. On a fundamental level, it goes against the rogue-like credo to learn through dying. Things will blow you up, melt you, swarm you, or push you to oblivion. On good, hour-long runs. And you'll say, well damn.

Further, there are times where I don't know why I won. Or why I was allowed to win. I mean I can look at my build in hindsight and go, "that's too powerful." The first time I beat the final boss, I just got watch from a distance while my build did the rest. Someone who has won a lot would probably say, "oh, that's cool," but it felt cheap and artificial to me. And it made losing more skill-based runs feel worse.

More, the gameplay loop really is run around, mow down large hordes of the same enemies and grab items. Find an frustratingly obscure teleporter, and start over. I can hear people say that I don't understand the game, and yes I got to experience the hype moments, hype movement, and hype builds. But, if we are honest with ourselves, that really is the cycle.  That is the core of it. On particularly bad runs, I find myself saying, "What am I doing with my life? What a waste of a day on repetitive bull-crap."

Probably most importantly, the game is addicting, and not in a good way. When I catch myself saying "this is the run" for the third time that day with bloodshot eyes, I know I'm in the danger zone. Or, "one more try," after playing for 4 hours. I've got a family. I can't be binge-playing games anymore. It's one of those rogue-likes that hits hard for gamblers. 

Lastly, this game is buggy. "Gearbox, am I right?" Yes and no. I bought this game pre-Gearbox, and my first three playthrough were so comically buggy that I uninstalled the game afterwards, saying, "I don't think this game is ready." Even now, the game will crash on good runs for no reason (especially Abyssal Depths for me, even when not a lot of creatures), and behave oddly on others.

With all that, it is a good game. It feels cool to discover. It has a good sense of mystery and exploration about it.

I really wanted to like Risk of Rain 2, but after 30 minutes of playing, it felt slow and a bit boring. The early game pacing is too sluggish, and while I know the appeal is supposed to come from stacking items and scaling power, it just didn‚Äôt hook me.

As someone who enjoyed Returnal, Risk of Rain 2 felt like a watered-down version without the tight combat and cinematic polish. The randomness and chaos didn't make up for the lack of immediate engagement, and it left me wanting more substance.

If you enjoy slower, co-op roguelikes that focus on item synergy over time, this might be your thing. But for me, it just didn't live up to the excitement or challenge I was hoping for.

It's been effectively a month since the DLC came out for ROR2. Why am I not leaving the review there? It also broke the core game. This game is on my top 3 all time... until the update popped up and made the game objectively worse. 90+% of my time is spent in the hardest difficulty, just for some perspective. 

Real quick, a list of things that are GOOD about the DLC:
-The soundtrack SLAPS. Top three all time soundtrack without a question, probably #1. The new map songs are just as good. 
-The new maps are a great addition to the game

And that's it. I guaruntee this game wasn't play tested to any sort of degree. The best example of this is that the bosses laser and the mini boss lasers WERE SYNCED TO FPS. WHO DOES THIS?
- 80+ percent of the new items are insta-scrap. The knockup item is garbage, the green thorn does nothing, the split damage is a negative in many cases, and that's just the start. On the subject of items, the sale star should be a red tier. It makes some runs absolutely non-fun when used properly and makes command artifact just dumb (with current scaling). 
- Chef is comically bad. He feels bad. His combos suck. His abilities hardly synergize. He's a 1 trick. I don't know how you have multiple good mods to look at and this is absolutely a worse version of any of them. 
- Speaking of which, scaling is hot garbage now. You'll get to stage four and die before you even spawn (because bad guys can spawn before you!?). They claimed to fix the issue where on stage one you'll be waiting around... I'm not sure I've noticed it being any better.
- 'Gilded' is absolute garbage. They have WAY WAY too much health, on top of the shield. PICK ONE.
- I swear chance shrines are bugged and I fail 80% of the time now. My friends I play co-op agree. 
- A simple bug, the primary attack the Vagrants do are unable to be attacked in multiplayer. This has been since day 1 of the DLC. 
- The new small worms are overtuned, and are basically to be ignored if gilded and you're not meme-tier broken. 

It's been nearly a month since the last patch and my most of my complaints still exist. 
All of this leads to the game feeling WORSE after the one or two patches AFTER the game broke from the DLC. They then have let the game sit without any real fixes for i believe 3+ weeks... AFTER TAKING EVERYONE'S MONEY.

Risk of Rain 2 is a multiplayer roguelike that keeps surprising you every time you play. After putting in over 69 hours, I can say that this game continues to deliver an enjoyable and challenging experience, even after so much time.

Graphics and World Design
The transition from 2D in the original game to full 3D in Risk of Rain 2 was handled beautifully. The worlds are vast and detailed, and combined with the atmospheric soundtrack, it creates a sense of endless adventure. However, some enemy designs can feel a bit repetitive after many hours of gameplay.

Gameplay and Mechanics
The gameplay is fast-paced and satisfying, with each run feeling different due to the randomization of items, enemies, and stages. The variety of characters, each with unique abilities, adds depth and replay ability. Building your character through item stacking is one of the most addictive aspects of the game, as it allows for crazy and overpowered combinations that can change the course of a run.

Difficulty and Challenge
Risk of Rain 2 is not an easy game. It starts off manageable, but as the difficulty scales over time, the chaos ramps up quickly. The mix of challenging enemies, boss fights, and the constant pressure to find a teleporter before things get too hard keeps the adrenaline high. It's punishing at times, but that's what makes victory feel so rewarding.

Multiplayer Experience
Playing with friends enhances the experience significantly. The cooperative nature of the game, combined with the frantic pace, makes it a blast to strategize and survive together. That said, the game can also be enjoyed solo, though the difficulty spikes a bit more.

Final Thoughts
After 69+ hours, Risk of Rain 2 still holds up as an engaging and fun roguelike. While there are moments where certain aspects may feel repetitive, the dynamic gameplay, variety of characters, and chaotic action make it a game that's easy to come back to. Whether you're playing solo or with friends, it's a thrilling challenge that keeps you on your toes.

Risk of Rain 2 Review
 
     I started playing this game not knowing anything about it and slowly but surely it has become one of my all time favorite rogue lites.  I struggle to think of a game that's come out in the past five years that has such unique art and gameplay.  Every character in this game plays completely different from the next and every run can have endless possibilities due to the wealth of items you can find.  I've spent hours trying to unlock alternate abilities for each survivor, get new characters and generally trying to see all the game has to offer.  However, the deeper I go the more I find and its been a while since I've had a game hook me like this. 
   
 Buy or Pass? 
    If you like rogue lites and third person action games: buy this.
    If you dont like to have fun: this isnt for you onto the next.

I have 338 hours in this game.  330 of which were pre seekers of the storm.  They have butchered my favorite game.  The new enemies are not fun.  The new elites are not fun and unfair.  The new items are poorly designed and just water down the item pool and make runs harder.  While the new stages and music are fantastic they cannot even come close to make up for the absolute assassination that gearbox committed on this game I once loved.  There are items that also genuinely just screw you over, and I'm not talking about the lunars.  The Unstable transmitter has killed me on multiple occasions.  The new survivors are also nothing special.  Seeker is is a buggy mess and her abilities are unintuitive and often get you killed.  Chef is a worse version of the mod that has been out for over a year.  And I haven't even gotten the false son yet.  That leads me to the next problem, the mods.  So many mods are broken because gearbox decided to fuck up the code of the game so badly.  Mods that have worked through every major update now are defunct and most likely will not be updated because why would a mod developer waste their time on fixing a mod for a game that is now worse.  Base risk of rain and the Survivors of the Void are fantastic but i cannot in good faith recommend seekers of the storm.  I will change this review if gearbox ever decided to overhaul the update (unlikely).  I want the best for this game and that means massive changes to the new content.  Gearbox is a spiritually spent money hungry company now so i doubt there will be any updates in the future for this wonderful game.  Here's hoping that I'm wrong but i doubt so.

Game-Wise:
I really enjoyed this game and what it had to offer. I had some trouble at it first resulting in my FIRST win at a in-game time of 30 Hours (No, I am not referring to the timer within the game like 30 hours on a singular run, jeez, the brain would be begging you to go outside or sleep). Every character played differently with some being very fun, or maybe, a little goofy to use. This game was quite fun just don't rush and soft lock yourself within the Bulwurk Ambry (I think that is what it's called). It sucked when I ruined a good run cause I immediately picked up the Artifact before the rings around it fell, resulting in that ;-; (Or I was just unlucky and the game had a bug/glitch there)

Achievement-Wise:
Some of the Achievements on this game feel really RNG, specifically the Ethreal and Purified Freedom (SOTS DLC Exclusive). Ethreal is the basically the no-hit challenge with Mercenary but unless you have spent several hours on that one character, you only really have a fighting chance with either trial and error OR what artifacts are being used in the Prismatic Trials. And the other Achievement, well, do you know how hard it is to find a Altar of Gold. I mean yeah you could use the Bazaar to increase your odds but the chances are still low. Either way every Achievement was fun to collect because not only did you do the challenges it had to offer but you were also rewarded in the end with something new. I shall still hate on those TWO specific Achievements I mentioned but overall, 8/10 with Achievements.

This game is amazing. There are so many factors of replayability it's incredible; so many combinations of items with their own synergy that work differently for different characters who give different experiences in their own right. Artifacts adding unique modifiers give you so many ways to change up the gameplay to give you something fresh.
The system of progression is something I'm surprised not more games use. Having achievements grant new items and characters rewards the player for playing more and trying to go for different item builds, so there's more than just bragging rights for doing certain tasks.
The soundtrack is one of if not the best soundtracks I've ever heard, each track setting an excellent atmosphere that seems to fit no matter the situation.

Takes the rouge-like genre and turns it into a masterpiece. The variety of characters and their respective abilities, combined with the randomness of loot drops throughout the levels, make for every run to be different. At first, I didn't think it would have much replayability, but to my surprise, it did. 

I believe this game really shines when played with other people, as going through a journey with friends to reach an overarching goal is always what creates a good multiplayer game. Whether you decide to beat a final boss at the end or trying to last as long as possible while looping, it creates a pleasant atmosphere from the peace of the beginning of runs or the challenging intensity of the late-game. 

There's also many different ways to alter the game to set the atmosphere to what you find best. If you like the relaxing and chill nature of the early-game, go ahead and changes artifacts to something like the Artifact of Command to choose the drops you want. If you enjoy the intensity of challenging waves of enemies, you can enable artifacts like the Artifact of Death to make all players die when any player drops below 0 HP, Artifact of Evolution to make monsters receive items between stages, or Artifact of Vengeance to have evil versions of yourselves become enemies. If you enjoy breaking run monotony (which I feel the artifacts give you the most variety this way). you can enable things like the Artifact of Enigma to change your equipment after each use, Artifact of Metaporphosis to spawn as a random survivor (character you can select), and a few others that drastically change how one would normally play. 

The colorful and potent artsyle, as well as addressing many issues that affect previous rogue-like games (such as a lack of run variety), and interesting multiplayer create a masterpiece that one can enjoy no matter the pace they choose to select.

P.S this was written before Gearbox. I enjoy the passion put into this game by the devs, but not greedy corporations.

First off: I love RoR2! I've played hundreds of hours. If you haven't played it, buy the base game, right now!!! The reviews used to be overwhelmingly positive, until the new DLC tanked it. The base game deserves a high rating. Survivors of the Void DLC is also pretty good, and adds a fair amount of fun content. I recommend it as well. 

BUT....

DO NOT BUY Seekers of the Storm DLC. Yes, they fixed some of the bugs that were glaringly apparent at launch, but it's still completely under-cooked and uninspired. First, let's talk about the price. $15 is insane for an expansion of a handful of maps, 3 half-baked playable characters, and however many items (17 I think), when the base games is around $25 or less.  You aren't getting anywhere near double the content of the base game, yet they're asking you to pay more than half of the base game cost. 

The new maps are just okay, but probably the best part of the DLC. A couple of them are well designed and fun, and a couple are the opposite. 

The new characters feel like modded characters. Modded characters aren't polished, many of them are still fun as hell to play, but they all have one thing in common that makes the lack of polish acceptable; the're FREE!!!!!!!!!    The new characters are severely lacking in creativity and polish. Worse than that, they aren't really unique. They all kind of feel like an amalgamation of already existing characters, but not in a fun way. I found them boring. 

For me, the worst part of the DLC is the new items. They aren't fun. Most of them are defensive, so you almost don't even notice their effects. They don't make you feel more powerful when you get them. Some of them are just objectively pointless. For example: Knockback Fin. Causes enemies to pop up in the air like 5 feet when hit. What could possibly be the purpose of this? If anything, it's a hindrance. More often than not, an enemy is launched and then you miss them with subsequent shots. Dumb. I find myself avoiding almost all of the new items. Again, there are a ton of mods for items if you want to spice things up, but for FREE. 

To be clear; I don't mind paying for content. I want to support games that I spend a lot of time playing. But, nobody wants to be taken advantage of, and that's what this feels like. It feels like they leveraged the community's love for the game to price gouge and put out a product that would take just long enough to realize how bad it is that you won't be able to refund it. You'll spend 2 hours hoping that there's more, just to find out it's too late, and you're a sucker. 

I see myself as one of RoR2's biggest fans. I've loved it since early access, and I still do. Corporate greed has just gotten the better of the new DLC. Yes, Gearbox released a statement promising to make it right, but don't give them your money until they deliver. They've done literally the bare minimum so far, which is fix stuff that shouldn't have been released in the first place. The sell now, fix later model has got to stop. It's BS. I'm tired of it. You're tired of it. You're going to see a lot of reviews saying to cut the devs a break and it's going to get better. I'll cut the devs a break when they give us $15 of content. Right now, I see it only as a cash grab. 

I will change my review to positive if/when the devs deliver on their promises.

I get what people are saying. Gearbox messed up with the update that added Seekers of the Storm. But that doesn't mean that the game is inherently bad now, it's still one of the greatest roguelikes of this generation. Game is amazing. Gameplay is definitely different from the first game, as they added a whole 3rd dimension! Joking aside, I loved the first game, and this was a fantastic follow up. My friends and I have this on our permanent rotation of games we're always coming back to. Tons of playtime and content, plenty of bizarre and fun ways to spice things up.

Void DLC: Excellent addition to the game, new boss is a real challenge for existing meta builds, new worlds are beautiful, and homage continues to be paid to the first game and its established lore. Well done, well worth the money if you play this game regularly

Seekers of the Storm DLC: While initially a little buggy, I picked this DLC up September 16th, and have yet to have a single gameplay issue. I understand others had problems early on, but We have played probably 100 hours or so of the new DLC, in both solo and multiplayer, and have yet to have a problem. The one glitch I noticed is the environment logs from the new Versions of the Ambry are bugged and unlock the log for the old version. Aside from that, haven't had any issues. 

To address criticism, here's the opinion of a long time RoR player. I loved RoR1, and to have the amount of lore and fan service present in the worlds, survivors, and logbooks brought by this DLC was awesome. Chef is back and fun as hell, Seeker is a great compliment to glass cannon survivors, and false son brings a great dynamicism to play that keeps things exciting. I don't at all agree with people saying the new survivors feel flat, or uninspired.
The new worlds and path of the storm is an awesome addition and challenge to beat without farming in a timeless world, especially on monsoon and adds another fun side branch to longer runs.
Many of the new items have quickly become staples, and to those saying some of them are blah, let me remind you that items like the Hunters Harpoon and the Roll of Pennies are OG items and more blah than just about everything in this DLC (except maybe war bonds)

 I understand people were unhappy with the initial state of the DLC, but my whole game group is loving it, and no one's had a complaint. Who cares if its made by gearbox now, evidently they give enough of a damn to put in cool things like Providences sword and worms into the hatchery, deeper lore to the logbook entries giving us more insight into the brothers relationship, and new worlds that differ significantly from the ones we have thus far. Let me remind you that some games get no DLC or new content at all.

This game is an easy 10/10 recommend from me, and the DLCs if you can spare the cash and like the game are as well.

TLDR: I believe Risk of Rain 2 is one of the rare roguelikes that transcends its genre boundaries and placates a much larger demographic. Chances are, you'll love this game one way or another.

[h3]Balance[/h3]
I'm going to ignore prismatic trials, and all the weird wacky side content because I haven't really tried it. There are 3 game modes, that will surely encapsulate your preferred difficulty. Baby mode, human being mode, and testosterone supreme. I haven't trimmed my neckbeard in a little while so I prefer the latter, but every game mode escalates in a exponential curve, so you will find a way to lose one way or another. When you are choosing your difficulty it's really about how much time you want to spend on your run - I believe there is a healthy challenge in this game for everyone.

In every roguelike there must be RNG swings. Risk of rain has ups and downs, but a veteran of this game will almost certainly make every possible scenario work. In other words, get good :^).

[h3]UI/UX and QoL:[/h3]
If you have experienced the soul-crushing experience of dying on the 1st stage of this game's predecessor, you know how short runs can be. Risk of Rain 2 sacrifices the ludicrous difficulty for a more tenable difficulty curve, at the price of longer - and sometimes tediously long runs. Introducing the zeitgeist of the Risk of Rain 2 Gearbox era: the pause button. Who knew the 60 lines of code to pause threads would take a studio acqusition to achieve.

The Risk of Rain franchise lists as one of my top 10 favorites, but unfortunately its pristine game status has pulled the wool of retrospect over the proverbial eyes of the community. This game absolutely needed the QoL and UI/UX changes that gearbox provided. They went mostly under the radar, and I won't cover them all here but just about every gripe I had with this game has been accommodated. Read about it here: https://steamcommunity.com/games/632360/announcements/detail/4281321170606899294?snr=2___

Gearbox has provided other various features to make the game more accessible and transparent to users. Quality design should make information simple at a glance, and entirely transparent upon when scrutinized. You can now read the exact stats of items in game (why didn't this exist before?!). There is still a lot of information you could never possibly hope to acquire except by visiting the wiki, thank God for the dedicated people over there. Post-update UI/UX stands at a 7/10 for me.

[h3] Graphics [/h3]
I remember when I was invited to play this game upon release. I had no prior exposure, and expected RoR1 with more content and maybe a graphics overhaul. This game looks incredible, at least as good as it can without melting your GPU an hour in (actually it still kind of does). The dev team toed the line between minimalist performance and gorgeous, communicative graphics to make an incredibly stylized style that never sacrifices readability or performance. (PS check the umbrella settings in the gameplay tab that Gearbox added, a lotta good shit!).

[h3] Music [/h3]
HOLY FU3KIM0LI.

I hear a lot of praise for composers like Mick Gordon. Good game composers will make a reactive set of polygons feel like your Herculean victory story. Risk of Rain 2's composer Chris Christodoulou does the impossible with elated peaks of guitar riffs when you're fighting some titan of realms and the antonymic, quiet, mysterious ambience when you slip into the Bazaar Between Time. Try playing this game muted - it's simply not the same game.

I wanted to slip in a quick excerpt about sound effects and reactive audio. MAN this game makes it satisfying to be powerful. Crits, bleeds, missiles all have different chunky sound effects that make you feel infinitely rewarded for hitting the same boss for 3 minutes. Sound design in this game is one of the best I've seen, for allies and enemies alike. Nothing like the thick dopamine hit of firing a crit on huntress with tri-tips - even though I'm losing the run.

[h1] "Didn't Gearbox ruin the game?!" [/h1]
I tried to consolidate the changes into this section, but their UI/UX design needed to be mentioned. Let's break down the Pros and Cons, without the tribalism of angry gamer speak. There were some hiccups in the DLC release that are worth mentioning, but I was also overall happier with this DLC release than Survivors of the Void. Hear me out.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Aforementioned UI/UX/QoL changes - The biggest Pro IMO
- Holy CONTENT - Much more than the previous DLC with less price, and new skins for all base characters.
- New map design (GORGEOUS)
- The introduction of more revive mechanics - a much needed addition especially for multiplayer
- A more diluted item pool - it introduces more variety and counteracts the power creep of added void items

[b]Cons:[/b]
- New items feel poorly thought out, with several having little to no effect. It seems the devs maybe hadn't played this game enough to understand what is desirable in this game.
- New elites need some tweaks. I have heard some bugs that are absolutely absurd with the spawning of additional Gilded elites, and a late-game elite with percent health damage reflect was simply a poor idea.
- Some wacky, jagged bits on the new path. The new mini-boss has some bugs and knockback issues that need to be changed. Nothing a few patches won't fix.
- I was REALLY looking forward to Chef but after a few runs he definitely needs some buffs or an overhaul.

[b]Overall[/b]
Gearbox made a mistake, and fixed it quickly. There are still rough edges but the DLC is more than worth the price tag as of this moment. I will get more than an hour of playtime per dollar spent, which is more bang for my buck than most games will promise. Their dev team has been receptive, responsive, and transparent in what has been pointed out. This could have easily been a cash grab after how many sales it has already made, but they have been working hard to accommodate the concerns. Give it a shot; I believe Gearbox could make this franchise even better with time and patience.

The game is allegedly running well post-Seekers DLC. It has a well established modding scene for endless replayablilty and has an AMAZING soundtrack by Chris Chris the absolute goat, which remains one of my most listened soundtracks to this day.

However I can't in good faith recommend this game as Gearbox has set an awful precedent for their first update after purchasing the IP. They allowed it to be shipped in a disgraceful state, with completely broken game code and a laundry list of reproducible bugs that should not have gotten past QA. Modders have even thrown up hands and retired from the game due to how egregiously Gearbox tore the code a new one. This was even after the update had been delayed and cut into two parts, which had its own fair share of bugs that never got hotfixed until the full release.

On a personal level, one of the biggest draws of the game was the worldbuilding, where lore is spread out over environmental storytelling and sparse details over many logbook entries. Hopoo employed a lot of showing, not telling, not unlike the Fromsoft games. Unfortunately Gearbox came out the gates flailing with their first announcement trailer introducing voiced dialogue and filling in the blanks which Hopoo so carefully left up to interpretation, such as pseudo-retconning the ending of the first game to fit their new epic. Subtlety was never their strong suit (see: Borderlands), and the mystique of the world was tarnished in the process. It was like someone took over the Half Life franchise and let Gordon be voiced by Nolan North because they didn't understand the point of a silent protagonist nor have they the creative bearing to write around them.

The final nail in the coffin for my interest in the franchise was how Gearbox's massive blunder has caused a rift in the community. With all the criticism proliferating the airwaves a number of apologists has taken it upon themselves to push back against the negativity on behalf of Gearbox, pleading for others to change their reviews and shooting down any form of criticism of the game as issues the developers will inevitably fix. In any case, the whole mess reeks of poor management from Big G and I'd rather go back to supporting indie developers who treat their games with love and respect.

i love this game. i had sunk many hours into this game before SOTS and will continue to do so even in spite of my dislike for the new update - but gearbox's design vision for SOTS, and the changes to the game outside of it in its newest updates, have made the game much harder from a balance perspective. and it's in a way that makes the game tangibly worse than the very sturdy balance the game was in previously. (v1.2.4 specifically.) i can't recommend the game in the state its in now post-SOTS release because the game just isn't as fun anymore - it constantly ping-pongs between feeling unengaging and cheap. 

i like to think 100 hours in that i'm at least okay at the game, though i have favorites i understand the ideals of what each character does and how to optimize a build throughout a run to give yourself the best chance to win. but even if your goal playing on monsoon is just in obliterating - not going for mithrix as i am, just looping to get all the extra character skins and achievements - the amount of enemies you're running into at earlier stages feel so unbalanced. it's noticeably worse than it used to be, spawns are just off the fucking charts. elite elder lemurians at ~15 minutes into a rainstorm run and its even worse on monsoon with boss enemies. (i just had a run ended by three stone titan lasers at once two minutes after spawning into abyssal depths and it didn't feel great!) the new enemies they're throwing at you - specifically the gilded and twisted varieties of old enemies, as well as scorch wurms and the fucking child - have core design ideals that clash so hard with the other well designed enemies, and can make entire runs feel unfun when you die to them. child oneshots are annoying and gilded enemies are damage sponges to a RIDICULOUS degree, but scorch wurms are somehow worse than both with the fact that they're tanky as fuck for no reason, have big hurty AoEs which can hit you in the air, AND cant be attacked while they're burrowing in the ground. actual worst enemy in the game. dogshit on every level.

the DLC itself, if you buy it at that fat $15 price tag, doesn't even get you anything incredibly exciting - to be fair seeker is an alright character (though not my speed) and false son is fun but was quite broken on release and they're still having to fix shit with him. but chef? lmao. actively bad. the most undertuned character in the entire game. the new areas and boss fight you get feel boring at best and actively annoying at worst - if you loop a couple times climbing up prime meridian to get to him and oneshotting false son can be pretty easy, but approaching it from a timed run perspective many might do for a challenge, like people do against mithrix, makes the entire area's design flaws really stand out. the new boss fight is just a worse mithrix, and isn't fun or engaging in any different metric. i hate the 'run around and touch pillars to get your abilities back' bullshit, and false son's one hit kill beam being able to reach through the walls you're meant to hide behind is deeply tilting at the end of an especially hard run with how hard the game is overall now. the new stages are pretty, and the concept of the new artifact is great - handing down an item from a previous run to a new character's run if you can beat false son - but everything else? only one new equipment thats just a free res, and many of the new items (outside of my love Sale Star, who is forever innocent) either don't even work, aren't good, or are way too situational to add anything to runs. if you're not running Command artifact (which to be fair, i am 90% of the time) your characters are tangibly worse early with how you have to waste time trying to scrap the crap new items which add nothing to your character if you don't want them. and if you just decide to push through with them instead, you get savaged by early game gilded pest or brass contraption. like, wow, my knockback fin really came in clutch there!

when RoR2 is at its best it can still be really fun but i'm running into a wall trying to get the 100% completion with the game's balance in the state that it is. monsoon difficulty sucks right now, and i truly feel that after another 15 hours trying to get to grip with the games new balance, it's not me sucking, it's a significant series of design missteps and code issues that have fundamentally altered what was once a pretty fantastic game. between this and turning borderlands into a shell of itself, i hope randy pitchford catches every single red light on his commute home from work, every day, for the rest of his life. if you wanna pick up the game now do so with some caution - this update'll probably get better with time, but gearbox owning this franchise doesn't bode well for its future. coming big content updates might be even worse. enjoy it co-op with friends first, solo is enjoyable still but co-op is where this game's best. vanilla is still great, SOTV's good but SOTS is optional. it has great extensive mod support through thunderstore, try some of those instead!

This is the best roguelike I've ever played. Despite the recent update and DLC, the gameplay is still extremely fun, the character playstyles are varied, the environments are pretty, the soundtrack is phenomenal, the items are cool, the enemies have varied designs, and the lore is (oddly enough,) very interesting. 
As an employee of the UES Safe Travels, your mission is to find out what happened to the Contact Light in the previous game, gathering loot from the scattered crates dropped by the destroyed ship along the way, using Providence's teleporters to travel across Petrichor V. 
The game currently offers 4 different endings, 16 characters (each with their own unique unlockable abilities), 207 items, 61 enemies, 10 enemy modifiers ("elites"), and 28 environments.
If you like movement characters, one of the strongest characters in the game heavily relies on movement. If you like precise sniper-like characters, the "Survivors of the Void" DLC has you covered, if you like sacrificing health for damage, I recommend getting a friend to help you unlock REX, if you like AOE characters, beat the game and go nuts, if you prefer melee characters, there's a couple options, including the aforementioned movement character.
The game had a rough turnout recently under the acquisition of gearbox, but they managed to turn it around and patch most of (if not, all) the bugs, afaik.
This has become my favorite game currently, and I cannot stop playing it.
There are also two gay lizards in the abandoned aqueduct stage. Very nice.

Whether Hopoo did it or Gearbox, but I was unable to play on Monsoon and get high up in levels before dying, and now I cannot get past the lower levels.  The enemy spawn rate is ridiculous, the healing rate they give out is disgusting.

Whether using artifacts or not you just do not get enough items to survive.  Seeker isn't a bad class, but the characters are basically bullet sponges now.  This game is barely enjoyable.  Some enemies can knock you literally across the map and you cannot input any keys.  The "Xi Construct" boss attack effects are so bright that it is an epileptic concern.  Not only that but his hit box is horrific, and with the heal rate it's a sickening fight.

Hopefully the difficulty, and other aspects are worked on.

Risk of Rain 2 is truly an experience. I've now played this game on both Google Stadia, and Steam, with my total playtime being somewhere around 300 hours. From that time, I can say, without a doubt, Risk of Rain 2 is one of, if not my favorite Rouge-lite. I'd certainly recommend this game to anyone who likes rouge-lites. 
I will say, the game is not balanced, which is not surprising considering how the game works, but if you are looking for any semblance of balance, you wont find it here.
The game doesn't really pose much of a challenge, that may just be because of playtime, or the other games I have played, but to anyone who plays a number of games, I doubt they will have any challenge.
Onto another note, both of the dlc are worth it. Both Sots and Sotv add a multitude of items, and a rather large pool of items. They both add characters, who are all fun to some extent, and new areas, If you like the base game, buy the dlc.

A decent and fun rogue-like if you're playing solo. If you're playing in a group, however, be prepared for an hour plus of extremely unbalanced gameplay where some players run away with the game and leave their teammates barely participating. And make sure to have another game system at the ready in case you die, because you'll wind up sitting there while your teammates further widen the gap. When they finally do resurrect you, they'll have gotten so much stronger than you that there's basically no point in you still being there. I played over a dozen runs today, and only had one run over the course of nearly 5 hours that I actually felt I was contributing.

TL;DR--Multiplayer usually involves 1 or 2 players doing all the work while the other players just sit and watch. When you die, you end up sitting there with nothing to do, and when you respawn, everyone else is significantly stronger than you.

You have two unlocked characters to play at the beginning and you unlock more of them like in Isaac and Gungeon. There are no tutorials and story, but it's not hard to learn. You have a lot of pickups and items that can stack, an active item and also 3D printers. I don't get it why you lose all of your money at the start of the next world. It doesn't make much sense to me. Design of the game is nice, but I haven't played it since this new update. I heard players are complaining so I'm gonna check that out as well.

All of the negative reviews are valid. Flat out not gonna lie to you, reader. Gearbox was wrong to put out the dlc so early and some choices were made, but they're working on it, and they're doing a good job. The game itself is a masterpiece, and I can't recommend it more if you like fast paced chaos with skill and knowledge put into an hour of gameplay. the bosses are awesome (except that one), and you can loop to make your runs even more crazy. And while its far from perfect, you can depend on the modding community to fix whatever nitpick you have. Don't just listen to this guy for whether or not you're buying the game or not, but I recommend this game without a shadow of a doubt.

Fantastic game. It scratches the buildcrafting itch while maintaining rogue-like gameplay. The art style is very unique and the sheer chaos in the late game is so much fun!

I love the quirky character designs (especially Chef and Rex) and each one has a unique play style. Going for god runs and chasing achievements to unlock the alternate abilities and skins adds a goal-oriented progression that keeps each run interesting!

IMO this is the best indie game I have ever played and it is awesome to have watched it grow in popularity and gain major studio interest!
